awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Adaptive Tactile Picture Books for Blind Children during Emergent Literacy
awd_abstract_narration:
This research is motivated by the importance of a child's early experiences with picture books during emergent literacy, which is the period when a child gradually learns to read.  Picture books connect visual literacy, cultural literacy, and print literacy, which is crucial for a child's literacy development.  But only a limited number of children's books have tactile pictures accessible to blind children, and these typically cannot be modified to suit a child's particular needs.  With this in mind, the PI will investigate 3D printing as the technical mechanism to physically realize a variation of an adaptive tactile picture that is optimized for a specific child and to "make" just one unique copy of it, something which is not possible with conventional printing approaches geared toward mass production of a uniform design.  Achieving this vision will change the way tactile pictures are made available to visually impaired children; a parent or a teacher will be able to download a digital 3D model of a tactile picture book from a website, adapt the model for the child, 3D print the model, and read the resulting "one-of-a-kind" book together with the child.  Research products will include a website for sharing 3D tactile pictures and open source tools for creating them.

In this project, which integrates science, design, and engineering, the PI will exploit 3D printing to overcome the lack of adaptation in conventional one-size-fits-all tactile pictures.  Specific Aim 1 will establish a new experimental framework, based on large-scale dissemination to families and video-based behavioral observations of children, for scientifically studying 3D-printed tactile pictures.  Specific Aim 2 will uncover the principles to elicit preferences and abilities from a visually impaired child, and the adaptive transformations necessary to optimize the design of a tactile picture specifically for that child.  Specific Aim 3 will introduce technical innovations to optimize the 3D printing of tactile pictures, to simplify 3D modeling software to empower more people to model tactile pictures, and to automate certain repetitive and laborious steps using computer vision.  To achieve these goals, the PI will partner with the Anchor Center for Blind Children, the National Center on Severe and Sensory Disabilities, the Colorado Talking Book Library, and the National Braille Press, all of which are organizations with a shared interest in promoting emergent literacy development of visually impaired children.  Project outcomes will advance our understanding of tactile pictures geared toward visually impaired children, and of the tactilization process for storybook pictures.

por.por_cntn:
How can we use 3D printing to create accessible pictures for blind or visually impaired (BVI) children? 

It is critical for BVI children to develop tactile literacy in order to function in our society (e.g., interpreting a tactile map), receive education (e.g., reading a tactile bar chart), and succeed in a professional career. However, experiences needed to develop such tactile literacy are often too late and too few. A BVI child may not be exposed to a tactile graphic until they receive their first accessible math textbook in late elementary, which is much later than a comparative sighted child. Some BVI children may be fortunate to grow up in a supportive environment, where parents recognize the value of early experiences with tactile graphics and are willing to buy children books with tactile graphics. However, the selection of these children's books is very limited. To address this issue, this research project studies how to create more accessible tactile pictures for BVI children. Our vision is that BVI children can develop tactile literacy early rather than late, and have abundant rather than limited options.

Intellectual Merit

1. Design Guidelines: Given a picture in a children?s book, what is the best way to represent the picture?s visual contents as 3D-printable models? Working with a diverse group of stakeholders, including teachers for the visually impaired (TVIs), parents, and tactile artists, we developed guidelines to help tactile designers make important design decisions such as which elements are important to 3D model, which elements can be skipped to reduce clutters, how much an element should be enlarged to improve comprehension by touch, how much spacing is needed between elements to be distinguishable by touch, how elements can be arranged on a page to illustrate a scene that readers can explore by touch, and how scenes across multiple pages can be connected with the right tactile cues to help readers navigate a story. 

2. Tools: Given an idea for a 3D design, ideally following our design guidelines, how can we develop tools to enable a designer to easily implement that idea as a digital 3D model and 3D print the model as a physical object that a BVI child can touch? We developed a suite of novel software and hardware tools. For software tools, we created a new web-based GUI tool to enable novice users to design 3D models to illustrate a visual scene in a children's book. Also, we invented a new programming language called CraftML to illustrate a 3D scene using text, making it accessible even for BVI users to author 3D models themselves using this new language. On the hardware side, we invented a set of enhancements to 3D printers, such as the capability to 3D print distinct textures to help readers distinguish different elements in a scene by touch.

Broader Impacts

1. BVI Communities: At the individual level, a key part of our research methodology is to involve families with BVI children early. Thus, over the course of the project, we have sent our prototypes to hundreds of individuals, providing direct benefits to them. At the community level, we have engaged many BVI-serving organizations, including local organizations (Anchor Center for Blind Children, Colorado Center for the Blind) and national organizations (National Federation of the Blind).

2. STEM Education: The knowledge generated and tools developed from our research has been widely disseminated outside our lab. The most significant platform for disseminating our research findings has been the Build a Better Book (BBB) network. The mission of the BBB network is to teach middle school or high school students how to design and make accessible 3D books for children impairments. Students not only learn a wide range of maker technologies but also develop empathy toward users with different abilities and needs. BBB network?s members include STEM teachers running courses on maker technologies, librarians managing makerspaces in local libraries, and teachers for the visually impaired. The network has expanded to more than 12 states.

3. Student Training: This project supported the dissertation works of two PhD students. It also involved more than a dozen undergraduate students to gain research experiences. Moreover, the project included one staff member who is blind. 


In summary, this project has positive outcomes in terms of scientific contributions (publications, open source software, guidelines) as well as societal impacts (Build a Better Book). Moreover, it has opened up new avenues for research to further study how technologies can best support the literacy development of BVI children.
